area_name: Englemann Canyon (submitted as Ruxton Canyon, Manitou Springs)

content.description: Pretty fun, little problem. You basically stick to the arete and climb the west face. When you are at the top, it's best to stretch across to your left before topping out. Otherwise, it's really awkward.
content.location:
Follow the trail up the hill a little ways from

Arretion

, towards the left.

climbs.name: Impeach the Bushes
climbs.fa: Abe Schubarth, Willo Schubarth, Larry C. Schubarth

content.description: Lots of dirt, loose rock, and moss. Most cleaned off.
content.protection: Minimal, mostly medium to large nuts or cams. Belay tree at top.
content.location:
Pietra Schubarth, south of the cog railway station. You can't see it for the trees. Below prominent crag w/ 3 spires. You can walk-off.

Located on Moss Wall at the bottom of Tall Boy Crag.

content.description:
Basically named so because it is the first problem you can climb in the canyon, and...this problem is pretty typical of all boulder problems in the area (meaning gnarly, granite crystals covered in moss, and slopes).

It's best if used as a sit down start, but nothing too hard. Just fun to let your hands get used to the rock in the area.
content.location: At the start of Ruxton Canyon. It's the first boulder you see just before the gate on the right. It's impossible to miss.

content.description:
It's a nice, little V1+ problem. It is only a 3 move, low ball problem, but it's good for beginners to learn the basics of crimps and crystals.

It starts out with obvious footing on the right, but the rest of the climb is generally smeary. Your hands start out with a small crystal in the middle of a slope on the right hand side. I found that it was easier to wrap my thumb around it and cup the slope. On the left, you have a gnarly crimp angled slightly to the left. After that, you just stick to the arete and do what you have to do using the various crimps and crystals along the way.
content.protection: It is a low ball, so there really is no need for a crash pad, but there is a tree branch blocking a good portion of the landing zone. I would recommend having a buddy kinda pull it out of the way and spot you if you are a new climber. To the more experienced climbers I say, "don't fall"
content.location: If you park in the Bar Trail parking lot, you need to walk down the hill to the cog railway. You are going to want to head right up the road. The reason being, there is no parking except for residence. Once you reach the gate, you take the high road. Directly across from the giant boulder to the left, there is a little "trail" that cuts through the scrub oaks on the right hand side. You need to watch carefully for it, because the vegetation hides it pretty well. It takes you in about 20 yards or so, and "Arretion" is the first one on the left.

pathTokens: Englemann Canyon (submitted as Ruxton Canyon, Manitou Springs)
